framework_intro.para: Below is a suggested framework to help you structure this type of letter. There are spaces for you to add your notes and the content of your letter.
Remember that you can look the word up in the Oxford Advanced Learner's Dictionary.

step.label: What is special about a formal letter?

commentary.para: The important things to remember about writing formal letters are the layout, which follows particular conventions, and the language, which must be formal or semi-formal and polite, even when you are complaining. The content of your letter should have a clear, logical structure.
Below is the framework that was used to create this letter.
Write your address, but not your name, in the top right-hand corner.
Write the name, position and address of the person you are writing to on the left-hand side.
The date can go either on the left or the right under the address, or above the address on the left. It could also be January 31, 2010, (BrE) 31/1/10, or (NAmE) 1/31/10

step.label: How does the letter start and finish?

commentary.para: The writer doesn't know the name of the person he is writing to, so begins 'Dear Sir or Madam', and ends 'Yours faithfully'.
The writer took notes for each paragraph before beginning to write.
The writer uses key words or phrases for a letter of complaint.

checklist.point: Use the framework to organize notes for your own letter.
Make sure the greeting and close match.
Have I put my address (but not my name) in the right place?
Have I put the name and address of the person I'm writing to in the right place?
Have I put the date in the right place?
Does my first paragraph make it clear why I am writing?
Have I made it clear what action I would like? (e.g. a meeting, some information, compensation, etc.)
Have I matched the greeting (Dear...) with the right ending (Yours...)?
Does my letter sound quite formal?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar and spelling?

paragraph.name: Your address
paragraph.tip: Write your address, but not your name, in the top right-hand corner.

paragraph.name: Name/title and address of the person you are writing to.
paragraph.tip: TIP Write the name, position and address of the person you are writing to on the left-hand side. If you are writing in American style use American spelling and punctuation e.g. write Mrs., Dr., etc.

content.prompt: Type the name and address here

paragraph.name: Date
paragraph.tip: TIP This can go either on the left or the right under the address, or above the address on the left. It could be written January 31, 2010, or 31/1/10 (both BrE), or 1/31/10 (NAmE).

paragraph.name: Greeting
paragraph.tip: TIP Use 'Dear Sir or Madam' if you do not know the name of the person you are writing to. If you do know the name, use the form 'Dear Ms Klein', 'Dear Mr Smith'. If you do not know the gender you can use 'Dear Chris White', but do not use both title and first name. If you are writing in American style and you do not know the name of the person you are writing to, you can use 'To whom it may concern'.

paragraph.name: Reference
paragraph.tip: TIP You can use a heading instead e.g. Poor service levels.

paragraph.name: Paragraph 1
paragraph.desc: Explain clearly why you are writing.

notes.para: We were passengers on flight LZ238 from London to Orlando, USA - July 23rd 2009. Want to complain about the service - several aspects.

content.para: My wife and I and our two children, aged 2 and 4, were passengers on flight LZ238 from London to Orlando, USA on July 23rd 2009. I am writing to complain about a number of aspects of the service we received.

paragraph.name: Paragraph 2
paragraph.desc: Explain the problem and how you were affected.

notes.para: When plane delayed, staff at the information desk were unhelpful. We were not given a voucher for a drink or meal - delay would be at least seven hours. So had to spend a large amount of money in the restaurant.

content.para: Firstly, when the flight was delayed, the staff at the airline's information desk were very unhelpful. We were not even given a voucher for a drink or meal, when it was clear the delay would be at least seven hours. This meant that we had to spend a considerable amount of money in the restaurant.

paragraph.name: Paragraph 3
paragraph.desc: Explain any further problem and the consequences.

notes.para: When able to board, families were not allowed to board first - but we had paid for this. So we were not able to sit together - children became distressed.

content.para: Then, when we were finally able to board, families were not allowed to board first, although we had paid for this. As a result we were not able to sit together, making our children, already very tired, extremely distressed.

paragraph.name: Paragraph 4
paragraph.desc: State clearly what action you wish the company to take.

notes.para: Legal requirement for airline operators to provide refreshments if there is a delay. I expect compensation for this and no priority boarding although paid for.

content.para: It is a legal requirement for airline operators to provide suitable refreshments in the event of a delay. I would therefore expect some compensation for your failure both to comply with this regulation and to provide us with the priority boarding for which we had paid.

paragraph.name: Ending
paragraph.desc: General comment. Say you would like a quick reply.

notes.para: Enclose boarding passes and look forward to hearing from you shortly.

content.para: I enclose our boarding passes andlook forward to hearing from you shortly.

paragraph.name: Closing
paragraph.desc: Sign your name and print it underneath. Give any other contact details e.g. email.
paragraph.tip: TIP If you begin 'Dear + a name', end 'Yours sincerely'. Use 'Yours faithfully' here if you have begun 'Dear Sir or Madam'. In American style end your letter 'Sincerely', 'Sincerely yours', (if you use Dear + a name) or 'Yours truly'.

content.prompt: Type 'Yours sincerely', 'Yours faithfully' etc, and your name
